abstract.p: Excerpts from previously published reviews of restaurants near Brooklyn Museum (Good Eating column) (S)

block.p: ''The Dinner Party,'' Judy Chicago's landmark multimedia installation celebrating the role of women in Western civilization, has moved to a permanent home in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art at the Brooklyn Museum. The work features a table with 39 place settings, each representing a woman in history. Smaller parties can be seated at these nearby restaurants.

BEAST (718) 399-6855; 638 Bergen Street (Vanderbilt Avenue); $; $25 and Under: 4/20/05. The name is inspired by the fondness of the owner, Deborah Bicknese, for mythological monsters. The menu offers inventive plates that Ms. Bicknese and her co-chef, Megan Fisk, call tapas. But most of them -- like the light potato, mushroom, spinach and egg tortilla and the lager braised short ribs -- are large enough to pass around the table.

CHRISTIE'S JAMAICAN PATTIES (718) 636-9746; 387 Flatbush Avenue (Carlton Avenue); $; $25 and Under: 7/19/06. This 40-year-old Prospect Heights stalwart recently moved half a block closer to Prospect Park on Flatbush Avenue. The meat fillings at Christie's are encased in a turmeric-yellow pastry, made with a fair amount of suet that splits into layers and shards when you bite into it, revealing the moist, nearly puréed meat filling within.
Beyond the patties, there is a full menu of jerk chicken, curried goat, braised oxtails and an assortment of baked goods.

FRANNY'S (718) 230-0221; 295 Flatbush Avenue (Prospect Place); $; $25 and Under: 6/16/04. Franny's belongs to a new wave of pizzerias where high-quality ingredients, like house-cured meats and farmstead cheeses, elevate humble pies. The nicely charred bottoms and puffy rims taste faintly of wood smoke, and thin centers hold their own against superior toppings.
In addition to pizzas, Franny's serves crostini, house-cured meats like pancetta, soppressata, coppa and mortadella, and small plates like wood-roasted broccoli or leeks.

GARDEN CAFE (718) 857-8863; 620 Vanderbilt Avenue (Prospect Place); $$; Diner's Journal: 6/25/04. This tiny spot has a small but worshipful following. John Policastro's menu is ever-changing, the napkins are thick, the service by his wife, Camille, is warm and the portions are generous.
The current menu includes asparagus soup with braised leeks and basil cream, and guinea fowl breast with sweet and sour cabbage and green onion mashed potatoes.

RESTAURANT SORREL (718) 622-1190; 605 Carlton Avenue (St. Marks Avenue); $$; Article: 8/31/05. Restaurant Sorrel is an airy setting for a market-driven menu created by Alexandre Tchistov, formerly of 360 in Red Hook. Among the current offerings are roasted beets with horseradish goat cheese and walnuts, and pan-seared sea scallops with enoki mushrooms and pea shoots.
